title: How to Use Avocado

steps.headline: Mix avocado in a smoothie.
steps.description: Swap ¼ of a medium avocado into your morning smoothie in place of a banana. It adds a rich, creamy texture to your drink and reduces the total amount of sugar. If you miss the sweetness of the banana, add a teaspoon (7 g) of honey to your avocado smoothie. Blend ¾ cup (170 g) of grapefruit, 1 cup (30 g) of spinach, ¼ of a medium avocado, 2 scoops of protein powder, ¾ cup  (176 ml) of cold green tea, and 1 teaspoon of honey (7 g) in a blender for a delicious smoothie.

steps.headline: Create avocado energy bars.
steps.description: Process 1 ripe avocado, 1 cup (170 g) of pitted dates, and 1 cup (140 g) of toasted slivered almonds in the food processor. Fold ½ cup (75 g) of sunflower seeds, ¼ cup (100 g) of cocoa powder, ½ cup (30 g) of shredded coconut, and ¼ cup (40 g) of chia seeds into the mixture. Spoon the mixture into an 8 in x 8 in (20.32 cm x 20.23 cm) greased, lined baking pan, pressing it down with your hands. Refrigerate the mixture until firm and then cut it into rectangular bars. These bars are great for a healthy breakfast on the go when you don’t have a lot of time. These bars should take about 2 hours to firm up in the refrigerator.

steps.headline: Make avocado-banana pancakes.
steps.description: Use a 1:1 ratio of avocado to banana to make a healthier version of your favorite banana pancakes. Mash the avocado and banana together, and use the fruit mash in place of the mashed banana. The result is a subtle, creamy pancake that has less sugar, so you can use more maple syrup guilt-free! For an extra dose of fruit, add sliced bananas and diced avocados on top of the pancakes. For example, if your pancakes call for 2 cups of mashed bananas (600 g), use 1 cup of mashed bananas (300 g) and 1 cup of mashed avocado (300 g) instead. For a delicious pancake batter, mix 2/3 cup (85 g) of whole grain flour, ½ cup (64 g) of all-purpose flour, 1 tablespoon (13 g) of brown sugar, 2 teaspoons (8 g) of baking powder, 1 ripe mashed avocado, 3 bananas, 1 cup (235 ml) of milk, 2 large eggs, and a splash of vanilla extract. Pour your pancakes into a greased pan, flipping each after about 2 minutes. Enjoy!

steps.headline: Bake an egg in your avocado.
steps.description: Set your oven to 450° F (232° C). Cut your avocado in half, and remove the pit. Sprinkle each half with hot sauce and salt, and crack an egg into the hollow in the center of each half. Bake the avocado on a sheet pan for 12 minutes or until the egg is set. Mix up your egg breakfast by adding salsa, cheese, or any other toppings you like to the avocado.

steps.headline: Substitute mashed avocado for unhealthy fats in baked goods.
steps.description: Make your breakfast muffins and quick breads healthier by substituting avocado for the required quantity of butter, sour cream, or shortening. You’ll reduce the amount of saturated fat and gain additional vitamins and minerals. For example, if your recipe calls for 2 tablespoons (28 g) of butter, use 2 tablespoons (28 g) of mashed avocado instead. Reduce your oven temperature by about 25% when substituting avocado. The substitution will also likely increase baking times. Check your goods when they would normally be ready. If they’re not finished, check them again at 2 minute intervals until they are done.

steps.headline: Put mashed avocado on toast.
steps.description: Mash 1 whole, pitted avocado with a squeeze of lemon juice, a pinch of salt, and a splash of olive oil. Mix it together and spread it on a toasted piece of bread. Sprinkle it with chili flakes and drizzle it with additional olive oil, if desired. Top your avocado toast with sliced tomato or a fried egg for a new twist.

methods.name: Using Avocado as a Dressing or Side Dish

steps.headline: Whip up an avocado salad dressing.
steps.description: Put 1 ripe, pitted and peeled avocado, 1 cup (235 ml) of orange juice, ½ cup (117 ml) of lime juice, 6 tablespoons (127 g) of honey, and a pinch of salt in a blender. Run on medium-high until smooth. Use this creamy dressing on your favorite salad in place of a sweet vinaigrette.

steps.headline: Mash it into guacamole.
steps.description: Mix 4 mashed ripe avocados with ½ of a minced small onion, 1 ripe diced tomato, 2 diced Serrano peppers, a squeeze of fresh lime juice, and salt, pepper, and chopped cilantro to your taste. Eat the dip with tortilla chips for a rich and delicious Mexican treat. If you don’t have all the guacamole ingredients on a hand, a quick shortcut is to mix a couple of teaspoons of salsa into a mashed avocado.

steps.headline: Create an avocado salsa.
steps.description: Make a heart-healthy salsa by mixing together 1 ripe diced avocado, 1 peeled and diced orange, ½ cup (75 g) of chopped cucumber, ¼ cup (250 g) of diced scallions, 1 finely diced jalapeno, 1 tablespoon (5 g) of fresh cilantro, a dash of salt, and a squeeze of fresh lime juice. Stir the ingredients together in a bowl, and eat with chips or use it to top fish or chicken. Change up your salsa game by mixing chopped avocado with corn, black beans, lime juice, and chopped tomato for a Mexican-inspired salsa.

steps.headline: Try avocado hummus.
steps.description: Blend 2 ripe avocados, 1 15-oz (430 g) can of garbanzo beans, 1 large clove of garlic, 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of fresh lemon juice, and a dash of salt and pepper in your blender. The result is a smooth, creamy dip you can eat with a pita, multigrain crackers, or tortilla chips.

steps.headline: Make avocado soup.
steps.description: Heat 4 cups (940 ml) of chicken broth, 1 large diced sweet potato, 1 diced small onion, 2 teaspoons (14 g) of honey, ¼ teaspoon (0.5 g) of cumin, ¼ teaspoon (0.5 g) of salt, and chipotle powder to taste in a stock pot over medium heat. Bring it to a boil, and cook it for about 10 minutes until the potatoes are tender. Let it rest on the stove to cool for 10 minutes. Using an immersion blender, puree 1 avocado into the cooled soup. Garnish the soup with chopped avocado for extra healthy fats. The avocados will add a rich creaminess without the saturated fat of heavy cream.

steps.headline: Cut up some avocado fries.
steps.description: Slice your avocado into strips, dip them in a raw egg seasoned with salt and pepper, and then dip them in breadcrumbs to coat. Bake the avocado fries on a sheet pan like regular oven fries at 400° F (204° C). Bake them until the outside is crispy, about 10-12 minutes. Dip your avocado fries in a cooling Greek yogurt dip for extra protein, or sprinkle them with hot sauce for a kick.

steps.headline: Put avocado on your salads.
steps.description: Add some extra nutrition to your salads by putting chopped avocado on top. You can use avocado in cobb-style salads with proteins and cheese, fruit salads with citrus, or everyday green salads.

steps.headline: Add slices of avocado to your sandwich.
steps.description: Add some richness to your hamburger, BLT, or club sandwich with a layer of avocado. If you’re looking for a decadent treat, you could try adding avocado to your grilled cheese.

steps.headline: Garnish your tacos with avocado.
steps.description: Add cubed avocado to your tacos as a garnish. It’ll add some beautiful color and richness to your meal without all the saturated fat of sour cream or cheese.

steps.headline: Place some on your chili or soup.
steps.description: Top your chili with chopped avocado and your favorite fresh herbs for some additional flavor and texture. Even if you’re not a chili fan, avocado works just as well as a garnish on black bean or tortilla soup, too.

steps.headline: Top your fish or chicken with cubed avocado.
steps.description: Add some greenery and extra nutrition to your meal by adding cubed or sliced avocado on top of your protein. It can replace cheese and other creamy ingredients for a rich topping you don’t need to feel guilty about.

methods.name: Using Avocado in Your Beauty Routine

steps.headline: Remove your makeup with avocado.
steps.description: Rub a cotton ball over the cut face of an avocado to collect its essential oils. Use the cotton ball to wipe off stubborn eye makeup, such as mascara, without the stinging. Don’t wipe off the avocado oils after removing your eye makeup. Rubbing them into your skin can provide a great dose of vitamins A and E.

steps.headline: Make a face mask.
steps.description: Mash 1/2 an avocado with a teaspoon (7 g) of raw honey. Rub the mixture over your face, and let it sit for 10 minutes. Wash it off to reveal beautiful, hydrated skin. If you have acne-prone skin, try mixing a little yogurt into the mask for some natural antibacterial power.

steps.headline: Create a nourishing hair mask.
steps.description: Combine a mashed avocado with ¼ cup (60 ml) of olive oil, and smooth the mix over dry hair for a dose of hydration. Let the mixture sit on your hair for 20 minutes, and then wash your hair with shampoo and conditioner as normal in the shower. If you’re prone to greasy roots, apply the mask only to the middle and ends of your hair. Put a shower cap over the mask while it sits to keep from making a mess.

steps.headline: Moisturize your hands.
steps.description: Mash 1 ripe avocado with 1 ripe banana. Rub the mixture over your hands and nails, letting it sit for 10 minutes. If you like, you can place your hands in sandwich bags to keep from making too much of a mess while you wait. Wash off the mix, and enjoy your soft, supple hands.
